speaker: Elena
text: The phrase 'Who will guard the guards themselves?' feels more relevant now than ever. The idea that any institution, once created, inevitably starts serving its own interests seems incredibly cynical, but the evidence is hard to ignore.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Cynical, perhaps, but historically accurate. Juvenal wrote it about marital fidelity, but it applies perfectly to statecraft. The article's point about DOGE is just the latest iteration.

speaker: Elena
text: But the scale of the resistance to DOGE was astonishing. Federal employee unions, judges, politicians... it was a full-court press against efficiency. You'd think everyone wants less waste.

speaker: James
text: They want less waste that doesn't affect *their* jobs or *their* programmes. Parkinson's Law is less a theory and more a natural law of organisational physics, wouldn't you say?

speaker: Elena
text: I think it goes deeper than just work expanding. The article talks about the Roman bureaucracy under Diocletian, where 'the number of recipients began to exceed the number of contributors.' That's not just Parkinson; that's systemic capture.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. Augustus created a professional civil service out of necessity. You can't run an empire with a part-time Senate. But then it just... kept growing.

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly. And it wasn't just Rome. Look at the Chinese examination system. Designed for meritocracy, it became a rigid barrier to progress, selecting for elegant essay writers, not innovators.

speaker: James
text: Selecting for people who understood the system, yes. Their 'century of humiliation' directly resulted from a bureaucracy unwilling to adapt to external threats.

speaker: Elena
text: But that's the scary part, isn't it? These weren't bad people. They were highly educated, dedicated civil servants. Yet their system became 'ossified'.

speaker: James
text: Personal virtue is no match for institutional imperative. The Janissaries are the most chilling example. Created as elite, loyal soldiers, they became a parasitic hereditary caste.

speaker: Elena
text: They murdered a Sultan, Selim III, just for trying to modernise the army. That's not just resistance; that's open rebellion.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] And Mahmud II had to literally destroy them with cannon fire. Thousands killed. That's the historical precedent for truly dismantling a captured bureaucracy.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? You're not suggesting we need artillery to reform the DMV, are you?

speaker: James
text: [amused] Not literally, no. But the point is, those institutions couldn't be reformed from within. They had to be broken because they couldn't be bent. Our article makes that quite stark.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, fine. I'll give you that the historical pattern is grim. But modern democracies have accountability, oversight. We don't have Sultans with cannons.

speaker: James
text: And yet, the Code of Federal Regulations has swelled from 10,000 pages to 180,000 since 1950. The EU adds 2,500 new regulations a year. Where's that accountability?

speaker: Elena
text: Those regulations are often in response to real societal problems. Environmental protection, financial stability...

speaker: James
text: And each one creates new jobs for bureaucrats to draft, implement, and enforce it. It's a self-feeding system, Elena. As Thomas Sowell pointed out, 'it is almost impossible to name a government programme that has been terminated because it achieved its objectives'.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... actually devastating. I hadn't considered that particular framing.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] It's a powerful observation. And it ties into what we discussed in 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West' â€” the internal rigidities that lead to sclerosis.

speaker: Elena
text: So, is AI really the game-changer here? The article makes a bold claim: a guard that doesn't need guarding.

speaker: James
text: It could be. AI doesn't need a pension. It doesn't form a union. It doesn't create work for itself. It doesn't resist its own obsolescence. That fundamentally alters the dynamic of bureaucratic self-preservation.

speaker: Elena
text: That sounds almost too good to be true. But Estonia is a real-world example. Digitally native government, filing taxes in minutes...

speaker: James
text: With a fraction of the per-capita government employment. They're already demonstrating what a lean, AI-enabled state looks like. That gives them a competitive advantage, as the article suggests.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, I'm genuinely persuaded by the *potential* of AI here. I can see how it could strip away layers of administrative fat that democratic processes have failed to touch.

speaker: James
text: It's the first tool in history that might offer a non-violent path to dismantling these parasitic institutions. That's a huge shift.

speaker: Elena
text: But what about the article's 'second future'? Where the bureaucracy just absorbs AI? Creating 'AI oversight officers' and 'algorithmic accountability managers'?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] That's the critical risk, isn't it? The EU's AI Act, for example, is already laying the groundwork for a new bureaucratic apparatus to regulate AI itself.

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly! If we need thousands of officials to oversee AI systems designed to replace thousands of officials, then what's the net gain? It just adds another layer.

speaker: James
text: You're right. That's the ultimate Parkinsonian outcome. The technology meant to streamline actually becomes another source of administrative growth.

speaker: Elena
text: So, while I'm hopeful about the *potential* of AI for efficiency, I'm still deeply sceptical that the human element of bureaucracy won't find a way to reassert itself.

speaker: James
text: It's a battle for institutional control. Can the sovereign power, or the people, really wield this tool to cut through the Gordian knot of bureaucracy, or will the knot simply grow around it?

speaker: Elena
text: Juvenal's question remains. And even with AI, the answer might still be... no one.
